costs per pupil. At the same time it should be readily admitted
that no mechanical device can substitute for the human interaction
between a competent teacher and his students. The real issue there¬
fore is to find ways of splitting the teaching process into two
basic segments which can be supplied by mechanical and electronic
devices on the one hand, and by the classroom teacher on the other.
This dual approach is not really new because it is in effect em¬
ployed whenever books or any of the other forms of audio-visual
aids are utilized. In fact, this is the obvious way in which
teachers, by avoiding a great deal of routine, can have the time
to concentrate on all facets of the learning process.
(9) It follows from the preceding point that if the teacher is to
devote himself more to the individual problems of his students,
he will only gain the required time by sharing the purely
instructional task with his colleagues on the television screen.
This recognition involves a reorientation of the classroom
teacher's attitudes and procedures, away from the role of a mere
transmission belt of information to that of a guide, interpreter,
and evaluator of student performance.
(10) In this connection, it should be recognized that the newer
teaching machines and self-testing devices are not merely
designed for mass instruction. There is a growing trend toward
individual instruction and study through such means as language
